narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was such a great place to learn about the history of African American thinkers and was very well organized in order to understand different aspects of African American thought. Obviously, there was a very limited capacity in terms of time to go through every thinker in depth but overall, the class was very informational and I would reccomend.
An in-depth analysis of the Western canon through the lens of race.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths are the instructor and the syllabus readings, but I do wish there was more class engagement early on and a more diverse range of African American thinkers in terms of different religious backgrounds

Strengths: balance of leftist and conservative arguments on key issues pertaining to Black liberation, easy to speak up in class
Weaknesses: harsh grading considering little feedback / guidance given on essays, could have used more breaks during class

Strengths 
-The course was well organized and comprehensive. 
-Wide range of thinkers and topics. 
-More African American thinkers explored than the traditional Black canon of Malcolm, Martin, DuBois, Washington, Douglass.
-The assignment load is fair, diverse, and clear. 

Weaknesses
- Some omissions that may have made the course stronger include the work of Toni Morrison, Audre Lorde, James Baldwin, Angela Davis, Stokely Carmichael, and Huey P Newton, to name a few. 
- The week on early Black Feminism would have been well complemented with works in more recent and contemporary Black Feminism.
- Professor Collins did explicitly address this at the outset of the course but it's worth noting here: some issue debates can be presented on the syllabus as though there was more of an even 50/50 intellectual split on the issue in the Black community than there actually is. This distortion I think is inherent to all syllabus construction when one is trying to capture has many perspectives as possible, but may pose a frustration to some students.
- The syllabus includes a lot of opinion pieces. I am pro non-traditional and more informal forms of scholarship on syllabi, but I think some of the shorter pieces on this syllabus were more un-nuanced and hallow than pithy and poignant and take up space from more substantial pieces.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The debates were good to keep up student engagement!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It's a great class to learn about African American thinkers and is an amazing alternative for the Classics requirement if you did not want to learn through the lens of the western canon
Yes, all students in EPE ought to take this class as they would the Classics in EPE class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
